title: How to Stop a Yawn from Forming

steps.title: Breathing through your nose helps cool the brain, which prevents yawning.
steps.content: Breathing through your nose helps cool the brain, which prevents yawning. Studies show that yawning helps cool down your brain, and prevent overheating. If you feel a yawn coming on, close your mouth and breathe through your nose instead—that may do the trick! [1] X Research source

steps.title: Keep an ice pack on hand if you’re feeling tired.
steps.content: Keep an ice pack on hand if you’re feeling tired. Whenever you feel a yawn coming on, press the compress on your head for 1-2 minutes. This will help cool your head down, and may stop your yawns in their tracks. [2] X Research source When your brain is overheated, you’re more likely to yawn. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Grab some refrigerated fruit or other chilled snacks.
steps.content: Grab some refrigerated fruit or other chilled snacks. As you feel a yawn coming on, munch on a chilled snack—this might stave off the reflex for the time being. [4] X Research source Chilled grapes, berries, or any other refrigerated snack would work well.

steps.title: Some believe that yawns boost oxygen levels in your bloodstream.
steps.content: Some believe that yawns boost oxygen levels in your bloodstream. Unfortunately, experts haven’t found a lot of evidence that yawns are linked to low oxygen levels. Still, deep breathing could be worth a try! If you feel a yawn coming on, inhale deeply and see if it helps stop the yawn. [5] X Research source

steps.title: You’re more likely to yawn when you’re in a warm environment.
steps.content: You’re more likely to yawn when you’re in a warm environment. Studies show that yawns actually lower your brain’s temperature; so, if you’re in a warm area, you’re more likely to start yarning. [6] X Research source If possible, turn down the temperature in your living space or work area—this might stop potential yawns in their tracks. [7] X Research source Studies also show that factors such as sex, age, humidity, and amount of sleep don’t have much of an impact your chances of yawning. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Change up your scenery so you feel refreshed.
steps.content: Change up your scenery so you feel refreshed. Staying in 1 place for a long time may lead to fatigue and yawning. Give your mind some stimulation by heading outside and breathing in some fresh, invigorating air. [9] X Research source If you stay in 1 area for too much time, you might start to feel tired.

steps.title: Dehydration and exhaustion go hand in hand, which leads to yawning.
steps.content: Dehydration and exhaustion go hand in hand, which leads to yawning. Drink plenty of fluids throughout the day—rehydrating might help keep the yawns at bay. Women should aim to drink 8 glasses (1.6 L) of fluid each day, while men should aim for 10 glasses (2 L). [10] X Research source Water, watermelon, and coconut water all great options to keep you hydrated. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Try to get at least 7 hours of sleep each night.
steps.content: Try to get at least 7 hours of sleep each night. Create a regular routine for yourself, where you go to bed and wake up at the same time, even during the weekend. If you don’t get a lot of sleep, you might yawn more frequently. [12] X Trustworthy Source American Heart Association Leading nonprofit that funds medical research and public education Go to source

steps.title: Some people attribute their yawns to other conditions, like allergies or acid reflux.
steps.content: Some people attribute their yawns to other conditions, like allergies or acid reflux. Although these remedies are not endorsed by medical experts, some found that decongestant tablets and antacids helped. [13] X Research source These remedies are situational and may not work for everyone.

steps.title: Call your doctor if you find yourself yawning a lot.
steps.content: Call your doctor if you find yourself yawning a lot. Excessive yawning could be a sign of sleep apnea, narcolepsy, insomnia, or something else. Describe your symptoms to a doctor, and see if they can help pinpoint the root of the issue. [14] X Research source
